title: Visual Analytics & Applications
text:
Welcome to ISSS608 Visual Analytics & Applications! This subject focuses on the use of tools like Quarto and Tableau to create visualizations to analyze datasets. This course is taught by Prof Tin Seong Kam for the AY2024-25 April term, so you will find my coursework on this website over the coming weeks.
I am a full-time business analyst, part-time MITB student, and I am looking forward to pivot into data science in the near future. My hobbies are gymming, painting and travelling. Feel free to reach out to me through the links provided in the navigation bar!

title: Hands On Exercise 1
text:
The code below uses p_load() of pacman package to check if tidyverse packages are installed in the computer. If they are, then they will be launched into R.

pacman::p_load(tidyverse)





exam_data <- read_csv("data/Exam_data.csv")

title: Hands On Exercise 1
text:
Data
First, let’s call the ggplot() function using the below code.

ggplot(data=exam_data)

title: Hands On Exercise 1
text:
Geom
Geometric objects are the actual marks we put on a plot. A plot must have at least one geom and there is no upper limit. You can add a geom to a plot using the + operator.
Examples include:

geom_point() for drawing individual points (e.g., a scatter plot)
geom_line() for drawing lines (e.g., for a line charts)
geom_bar() for drawing bars (e.g., for bar charts)
geom_jitter() to add a small amount of random variation to the location of each point
geom_map() for drawing polygons in the shape of a map!

title: Hands On Exercise 2
text:
There are several ggplot2 extensions for creating more elegant and effective statistical graphics. Let’s explore these features!

Getting Started
Besides tidyverse, four R packages will be used.

ggrepel: to provide geoms for ggplot2 to repel overlapping text labels
ggthemes: to provide extra themes, geoms, and scales for ‘ggplot2’
hrbrthemes: for typography-centric themes and theme components for ggplot2
patchwork: for preparing composite figure created using ggplot2

To check if these packages have been installed and to load them into your working R environment, run the below code.

pacman::p_load(ggrepel, patchwork, ggthemes, hrbrthemes, tidyverse)
